data.event: The county is named after James Madison, fourth President of the United States of America, and was first formed in 1806.

event.title: had occupied areas around Oneida Lake for thousands of years

data.event: Indigenous peoples had occupied areas around Oneida Lake for thousands of years.

event.title: 1683; at the time, the territory of the present Madison County was considered

data.event: English colonists established counties in eastern present-day New York State in 1683; at the time, the territory of the present Madison County was considered part of Albany County, with the city of Albany located on the Hudson River.
On July 3, 1766 the English organized Cumberland County, and on March 16, 1770 they organized Gloucester County, both containing territory now included in the state of Vermont.
